title: The ages of two people are in the ratio 3:4. After 10 years, their ages would be in the ratio 4:5. What are their ages? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let the rational between ages of two people be x. Hence their ages are 3x and 4x. After 10 years, their ages would be in the ratio 4:5. What are their ages? After 10 years their ages would be (3x + 10) and (4x + 10) and their ratio 4/5. (3x + 10) / (4x + 10) = 4 / 5 Cross multiplication 4 (4x + 10) = 5 (3x + 10) 16x + 40 = 15x + 50 16x - 15x = 50 - 40 x = 10 The rational is 10, therefore their ages. 1st person 3x = 3 × 10 = 30 2nd person 4x = 4 × 10 = 40 Thus their ages are 30 and 40 respectively. Answer their ages are 30 and 40 respectively.

Use the information you have to set up two equations. Let their ages be x and y. Today, 4x = 3y, or equivalently, x=(3/4)y In ten years each age has increased by 10, so we can write this as 5(x+10) = 4(y+10) 5x+50 = 4y+40 5x + 10 = 4y (5/4)x + (10/4) = y From the first equation, we know x=(3/4)y, so we plug that into our second equation for x…. (5/4)(3/4)y + (10/4) = y (15/16)y + (40/16) = (16/16)y (40/16) = (1/16)y 40 = y Back to our original equation, where x=(3/4)y, we use our derived value of y to solve for x: x = (3/4) (40) x = 30 So the ages (today) are 30 and 40.

30 and 40 now, 40 and 50 in 10 years. Since you didn't specify which part, felt it necessary to give both. Knowing the ratio needed to simply be 0.8, I set about an Excel table to do the work for me. Column A would have the the age of the first individual at the first age point, or basically the multiples of three. Ditto Column B, except with multiples of four. Column C would be 10 years later as our age of person A, so A+10, our numerator. Column D did the same with Person B, or B+10, the denominator. The final column, E, simply was C/D, given the desired target was 0.8, or 4/5. Drag, drop, and it matches up perfectly with 0.8. Furthermore, we can verify this in reverse. 30 vs 40 is a 3:4 ratio. Good. Now we add 10 to each side, and 40:50 is also 4:5. Both sides satisfied. Success!
